instruments.description: The list of instruments requested. It could be a selected few or all for each market.

BTC-USD.description: All the relevant data for the particular mapped or unmapped instrument id.

TYPE.description: Type of the message. This is used to be able to validate the fields and to give an indication of what data to expect in the rest of the object / array

INSTRUMENT_STATUS.description: Status of the current instrument, this is ACTIVE, RETIRED or EXPIRED.

INSTRUMENT.description: The internal exchange defined instrument id. This will be different from integration to integration as each exchange has different naming conventions.

HISTO_SHARD.description: Our internal shard for historical OHLCV+ (minute/hour/day) market data. Minute data is only held in the historical database for up to 3 weeks and we ship it to blob storage afterwards. The API utilizes multiple replicas of a single shard in a round-robin manner.

INSTRUMENT_MAPPING.description: The current mapping object for this instrument.

MAPPED_INSTRUMENT.description: The current mapping instrument id.

BASE.description: The current mapped base asset for this instrument. This value can change if assets undergo rebranding or if a more prominent asset takes over the symbol of an existing asset.

QUOTE.description: The current mapped quote asset for this instrument. This value can change if assets undergo rebranding or if a more prominent asset takes over the symbol of an existing asset.

BASE_ID.description: Represents the internal ID for the base asset (e.g., 1 for BTC). This ID is unique and immutable, ensuring consistent identification. Applicable only to instruments with a mapping.

QUOTE_ID.description: Represents the internal CCData ID for the quote asset (e.g., 5 for USD). This ID is unique and immutable, ensuring consistent identification. Applicable only to instruments with a mapping.

TRANSFORM_FUNCTION.description: The current mapping function for this instrument. For example, during mapping, instruments may be inverted when they originally trade from a less dominant to a more dominant pair. For instance, USD-BTC would use the function INVERT and be represented as BTC-USD.

CREATED_ON.description: The timestamp indicating when this mapping was created.

MAPPED_INSTRUMENT.description: The mapped instrument ID (it depends on the instrument type, for spot it is just BASE-QUOTE).

HAS_AMM_SWAPS_ONCHAIN.description: A boolean flag indicating whether the instrument has AMM SWAPs or not.

HAS_AMM_LIQUIDITY_UPDATES_ONCHAIN.description: A boolean flag indicating whether the instrument has onchain AMM liquidity updates or not.

FIRST_AMM_SWAP_ONCHAIN_TIMESTAMP.description: The Unix timestamp of the first observed liquidity update for this instrument on-chain. This timestamp represents the earliest recorded liquidity update. Updates are rare and may take up to 1 hour to reflect on the API if backfilled.

FIRST_AMM_LIQUIDITY_UPDATE_ONCHAIN_TIMES.description: The Unix timestamp of the first observed liquidity update for this instrument on-chain. This timestamp represents the earliest recorded liquidity update. Updates are rare and may take up to 1 hour to reflect on the API if backfilled.

LAST_AMM_SWAP_ONCHAIN_TIMESTAMP.description: The Unix timestamp of the last AMM SWAP observed for this instrument. This timestamp represents when the most recent AMM SWAP was recorded in our system. Data may be delayed by up to 1 hour and is indicative only. For real-time data, consult the latest tick endpoint or use this timestamp in the after_ts parameter of the AMM SWAPs by timestamp endpoint.

LAST_AMM_LIQUIDITY_UPDATE_ONCHAIN_TIMEST.description: The Unix timestamp of the last AMM liquidity update observed for this instrument. This timestamp represents when the most recent AMM liquidity update was recorded in our system. Data may be delayed by up to 1 hour and is indicative only. For real-time data, consult the latest tick endpoint or use this timestamp in the after_ts parameter of the AMM liquidity updates by timestamp endpoint.

TOTAL_AMM_SWAPS_ONCHAIN.description: The total number of AMM SWAPs processed for this instrument on this specific on-chain dex. This represents the cumulative updates handled by our system.

TOTAL_AMM_LIQUIDITY_UPDATES_ONCHAIN.description: The total number of liquidity updates processed for this instrument on this specific on-chain dex. This represents the cumulative updates handled by our system.

INSTRUMENT_MARKET_FEE_PERCENTAGE.description: The trading fee (in percentage) charged for each transaction that occurs on the market

INSTRUMENT_BASE_TOKEN_ADDRESS.description: The instrument base token address, retrieved from the zeroth index in the transaction log args property

INSTRUMENT_QUOTE_TOKEN_ADDRESS.description: The instrument quote token address, retrieved from the first index in the transaction log args property

ASSET_ID.description: The unique identifier for the asset the field is associated to.

SYMBOL.description: Internal mapped symbol for a specific asset

PROVIDER_KEY.description: Internal mapped Blockchain provider key for a specific asset

CHAIN_ID.description: This is the Id of the blockchain

IS_PART_OF_REORG.description: Is this block part of a reorg? this would happen when we get block reorgs due to a longer chain being published by some of the miners.

TIMESTAMP.description: The current block timestamp

RECEIVED_TIMESTAMP.description: The current block received timestamp

NUMBER.description: The sequential order of the block within the blockchain. Each block's number is one greater than the number of the previous block.

TIMESTAMP.description: The exact time when the block was mined. It's a crucial piece of information for tracking the chronological order of blocks.

HASH.description: The unique identifier for the block, generated using cryptographic algorithms. It represents the content of the block and is used for verification and linking blocks together.

PARENT_HASH.description: The hash of the previous block in the blockchain. It establishes the chronological link between blocks.

L1_BLOCK_NUMBER.description: The block number on Layer 1 where transactions are finalized.

CONFIRMATIONS.description: The number of blocks added to the blockchain after this block. More confirmations generally mean a higher degree of security and acceptance in the network.

VERSION.description: A version number indicating which set of block validation rules to follow. Miners can use this to signal readiness to enforce network upgrades.

NONCE.description: This is a random number used in the process of mining. It's combined with other block data to create a hash that meets specific mining criteria.

BITS.description: The total amount of gas consumed by all transactions in the block. It helps in understanding the efficiency of transactions.

SHA3_UNCLES.description: This stores the hash of the block's uncles, which are valid blocks that were not included in the main blockchain but can provide additional rewards to miners.

LOGS_BLOOM.description: The bloom filter that allows for efficient querying of event logs.

TRANSACTIONS_ROOT.description: The hash of the root node of the Merkle tree that organizes the transactions in the block. It enables quick verification of included transactions.

STATE_ROOT.description: This hash represents the state of the blockchain after all transactions in the block have been executed. It's used to ensure the consistency of the blockchain's state.

MERKLE_ROOT.description: The Merkle root hash, which summarizes all the transactions included in the block. It ensures the integrity of the transactions.

RECEIPTS_ROOT.description: This is similar to the transactions root, the receipts root hash is the root of a Merkle tree, but it stores the receipts of transactions, including information about their success or failure.

SEND_COUNT.description: The total number of messages or transactions that have been sent from Layer 2 to Layer 1.

SEND_ROOT.description: Merkle root used to track messages sent from Layer 2 to Layer 1.

MINER.description: This specifies the address of the miner who successfully mined the block. This miner is rewarded with cryptocurrency for their effort.

MIX_HASH.description: This is a 256-bit hash value. It's essentially a part of the proof-of-work mechanism used in Ethereum to secure the blockchain. This hash is derived from the mixing of various components of the block, including the nonce, timestamp, previous block's hash, and more.

DIFFICULTY.description: This indicates how hard it was to mine the block. It's adjusted based on the overall network's hash rate to maintain a consistent block generation rate.

TOTAL_DIFFICULTY.description: This field accumulates the difficulty values of all previous blocks, providing a measure of the blockchain's security.

CHAIN_WORK.description: The total cumulative amount of work in the blockchain up to and including this block. It's a measure of the blockchain's security.

SIZE.description: The size of the block in bytes. It includes all the data and metadata within the block.

WEIGHT.description: A metric for the block's size that considers both the non-SegWit and SegWit data, used to ensure blocks remain within the maximum block weight.

BLOCK_TIME.description: The time taken in seconds between mining the previous and current block. It's an important metric for understanding the network's performance and stability.

MEDIAN_TIME.description: The median time of the last 11 blocks. It's used to ensure the network's time consistency.

EXTRA_DATA.description: This allows miners to include arbitrary information in the block. It's often used to add contextual information or messages.

GAS_LIMIT.description: The maximum amount of computational work a block can contain. Each transaction consumes a specific amount of gas, and this limit prevents abuse of the network's resources.

GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas consumed by all transactions in the block. It helps in understanding the efficiency of transactions.

TRANSACTION_COUNT.description: This indicates how many transactions are included in the block.

BASE_FEE_PER_GAS.description: The base fee for each unit of gas in transactions. It's part of Ethereum's fee market mechanism.

WITHDRAWALS_ROOT.description: The hash value that represents a data structure containing information about the withdrawals that occurred in the block.

BLOB_GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas used by blob transactions within the block.

EXCESS_BLOB_GAS.description: The amount of gas exceeding the standard limit for blob transactions.

HASH.description: Transaction internal mapped hash. (For BTC transactions without SegWit data, this is the same as the txid. For SegWit transactions, this represents the hash of the transaction including the witness data).

TX_ID.description: Transaction ID, a unique identifier for the transaction, calculated as the double SHA-256 hash of the transaction data.

TRANSACTION_TYPE.description: The EIP-2718 type of this transaction envelope

NONCE.description: The number of transactions made by the sender prior to this one encoded as hexadecimal. It prevents duplicate transactions and maintains order in the blockchain.

INDEX.description: The position of the transaction within the block. Helps in identifying the order of transactions in the block.

TO_ADDRESS.description: The address of the recipient. Null when its a contract creation transaction

VALUE.description: The amount of cryptocurrency being transferred from the sender to the recipient.

GAS.description: The amount of computational work a transaction requires to be executed. This is used to determine the fees paid by the sender to incentivize miners to include the transaction in a block.

LOGS_BLOOM.description: The bloom filter that allows for efficient querying of event logs.

L1_GAS_USED.description: The amount of gas used specifically by the current transaction.

L1_BLOCK_NUMBER.description: The block number on Layer 1 where the transaction was included.

L1_BASE_FEE_SCALAR.description: A scalar value used to adjust the base fee on Layer 1 for the transaction.

L1_BLOB_BASE_FEE.description: The base fee for processing blob transactions on Layer 1.

L1_BLOB_BASE_FEE_SCALAR.description: A scalar value used to adjust the blob base fee on Layer 1.

L1_FEE.description: The total fee paid for processing the transaction on Layer 1.

L1_GAS_PRICE.description: The price per unit of gas for executing the transaction on Layer 1.

DEPOSIT_NONCE.description: A unique number associated with the deposit transaction to ensure the uniquness and order of deposit transactions.

DEPOSIT_RECEIPT_VERSION.description: The version number of the deposit receipt, indicating the format version used.

GAS_PRICE.description: The price the sender is willing to pay for each unit of gas. Together with the gas limit, it determines the total fee for the transaction.

INPUT.description: The data associated with the transaction, often used in smart contract interactions. It can contain parameters and instructions for contract execution.

RECEIPT_BLOB_GAS_PRICE.description: The total gas price of the transaction blobs.

RECEIPT_BLOB_GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas used by the transaction blobs.

RECEIPT_CUMULATIVE_GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas used by the transaction and all preceding transactions within the same block.

RECEIPT_GAS_USED.description: The amount of gas used specifically by the current transaction.

RECEIPT_CONTRACT_ADDRESS.description: This is the address created when a contract is deployed. The *TO* field should be null in this case.

RECEIPT_ROOT.description: Only transactions included in blocks before the Byzantium Hard Fork have this field, as it was replaced by the *STATUS* field.

RECEIPT_STATUS.description: The status of a transaction is "1" if successful or "0" if it was a failure or reverted. Only transactions included in blocks post-Byzantium Hard Fork have this field.

MAX_FEE_PER_GAS.description: The maximum fee per gas unit that the sender is willing to pay for a transaction to be included promptly in a block.

MAX_PRIORITY_FEE_PER_GAS.description: The maximum fee per gas unit that the sender is willing to pay for higher priority processing of the transaction.

MAX_FEE_PER_BLOB_GAS.description: The maximum fee per gas unit that the sender is willing to pay for higher priority processing of the transaction.

RECEIPT_EFFECTIVE_GAS_PRICE.description: The total base charge plus tip paid for each unit of gas.

ACCESS_LIST.description: This causes a transaction to warm (i.e. pre-cache) another addresses state and the specified storage keys, Available on EIP-2930 transactions.

ADDRESS.description: Internal mapped Block Transaction Access address state

STORAGE_KEYS.description: An array of storage keys associated with the address mentioned above. Storage keys are unique identifiers used to access data within a smart contract's storage on the blockchain. Smart contracts often store data in a key-value format, where the storage keys are used to retrieve specific values.

ADDRESS.description: Internal mapped Block Transaction Access address state

STORAGE_KEYS.description: An array of storage keys associated with the address mentioned above. Storage keys are unique identifiers used to access data within a smart contract's storage on the blockchain. Smart contracts often store data in a key-value format, where the storage keys are used to retrieve specific values.

ECDSA_V.description: This is part of ECDSA (Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm) signature. This value helps to recover which public key was used to sign the transaction. Calculated as (CHAIN_ID * 2 + 35) or (CHAIN_ID * 2 + 36).

ECDSA_R.description: This is part of ECDSA (Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm) signature. It is derived from the private key and the data to be signed.

ECDSA_S.description: This is part of ECDSA (Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm) signature. It is derived from the private key and the data to be signed.

Y_PARITY.description: This is a recent addition from July 2023 and could be used instead of the ECDSA_V. ECDSA_V would be used for backward compatibility.

TRACES.description: The detailed records of the steps and interactions that occured during the execution of this transaction.

ID.description: This is a unique identifier generated by combining the root trace type + transaction hash + trace addresses if available

TRACE_TYPE.description: The type of trace being recorded. It could be either "call", "reward", "suicide", "create", etc. depending on the type of action being traced

ADDRESS.description: This represents the address associated with the trace. This could refer to the contract address, external user address, or any other relevant address in the context of the blockchain transaction

ACTION_FROM.description: This specifies the sender's address initiating the action

ACTION_CALL_TYPE.description: The type of call made, such as "call", "delegate call", or "static call". This is relevant when one contract invokes another.

ACTION_GAS.description: The gas cost of executing the action. Gas is a measure of computational effort required for executing transactions and contract calls on the blockchain network.

ACTION_INIT.description: This is the bytecode that is executed to initialize the contract and determine its final code stored on the blockchain.

ACTION_INPUT.description: The input data for the action (encoded in hexadecimal). For contract calls, this data includes function signatures and parameters.

ACTION_TO.description: This specifies the recipient's address receiving the action, which could be a contract or an external address.

ACTION_VALUE.description: The value or amount of cryptocurrency involved in the action. This is particularly important for actions like transactions where cryptocurrency is transferred.

ACTION_AUTHOR.description: This specifies the sender's address that initiated or triggered a specific action within a transaction. It identifies the entity or account responsible for the action, such as a user or a smart contract.

ACTION_REWARD_TYPE.description: The type of reward associated with the action, which might include mining rewards, staking rewards, or other types of incentives.

ACTION_ADDRESS.description: This is the contract whose code and storage are being removed from the blockchain.

ACTION_REFUND_ADDRESS.description: This is usually an external account or another contract that the remaining Ether is sent to.

ACTION_BALANCE.description: This amount will be transferred to the ACTION_REFUND_ADDRESS. Itâ€™s typically represented in wei (the smallest unit of Ether).

RESULT_ADDRESS.description: The address where the new contract is deployed.

RESULT_CODE.description: This is the actual code that will be stored and executed on the blockchain, distinct from the init code that was used to generate it.

RESULT_GAS_USED.description: The amount of gas actually consumed by the action during execution. This can be compared with the initial gas estimate to measure efficiency.

RESULT_OUTPUT.description: The output data produced by the action (encoded in hexadecimal), often used for reading the results of a contract call.

RESULT_ERROR.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the result, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *execution reverted*.

RESULT_STATUS.description: The status of the trace. Common values include "1" which means success and "0" which means failure, indicating whether the action was executed without errors.

RESULT_REVERT_REASON.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the result, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *fail*.

SUBTRACES.description: Indicates the number of subtraces created as a result of the action. Subtraces are typically generated when a complex transaction or contract call triggers multiple internal calls.

ERROR.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the action, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *Reverted* or *invalid opcode*.

STATUS.description: The overall status of the trace. Common values include "1" which means success and "0" which means failure, indicating whether the action was executed without errors.

LOGS.description: The chronological records of all activities such as transaction executions, contract interactions, errors, and changes that occur within a blockchain network.

ADDRESS.description: The address of the contract or account that generated the log entry. It serves as an identifier for the source of the event or action that triggered the log.

INDEX.description: The position of the log entry within the sequence of logs generated by a transaction. It's usually an incremental integer starting from 0 for the first log in a transaction. This field helps in distinguishing and organizing logs generated during a transaction.

DATA.description: This contains the arbitrary data associated with the log entry. This data can vary depending on the specific smart contract and event that generated the log. It might include relevant information about the state change or action represented by the log.

TOPICS.description: An array of one or more indexed event topics. These topics are hash values of event signatures or indexed arguments. They provide a way to filter and search for specific types of events within the logs efficiently.

REMOVED.description: A a boolean indicator that signals whether the log entry has been removed or undone due to a chain reorganization or a consensus rule change. It helps applications differentiate between active and reverted logs. It is "true" if log was removed, otherwise false.

BLOBS.description: The current transaction blobs, null when there are no blobs attached to the transaction.

HEX.description: The raw hexadecimal representation of the entire transaction data.

TRANSACTION_INPUTS.description: The source of funds for a Bitcoin transaction.

TX_ID.description: Transaction ID, a unique identifier for the transaction, calculated as the double SHA-256 hash of the transaction data.

INDEX_IN_TRANSACTION.description: The position of a specific input or output within a transaction.

SEQUENCE.description: A number used to specify the order of transaction.

COINBASE.description: A special type of transaction input that is used to reward miners with newly created bitcoins.

TRANSACTION_OUTPUTS.description: The destination of funds in a Bitcoin transaction.

REFUND_TO.description: The address to which any potential refunds from failed transactions or excess fees will be sent.

L1_BASE_FEE.description: The base fee required for transactions on Layer 1.

DEPOSIT_VALUE.description: The amount of cryptocurrency being deposited into the Layer 2 network.

RETRY_TO.description: The address to which a transaction should be retried or redirected.

RETRY_VALUE.description: The amount of value associated with a transaction retry.

RETRY_DATA.description: Additional data or parameters required for retrying a transaction.

BENEFICIARY.description: The recipient address designated to receive the cryptocurrency.

MAX_SUBMISSION_FEE.description: The maximum fee a user is willing to pay for submitting a transaction.

TICKET_ID.description: An identifier for a transaction ticket, used to track and manage queued or pending transactions.

MAX_REFUND.description: The maximum amount of funds that can be refunded in a transaction.

SUBMISSION_FEE_REFUND.description: The portion of the submission fee that is refunded if a transaction is not processed as expected.

ORPHAN_TRACES.description: Traces that were part of blocks that were not included in the main blockchain due to a fork or reorganization.

ERROR.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the action, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *Reverted* or *invalid opcode*.

STATUS.description: The overall status of the trace. Common values include "1" which means success and "0" which means failure, indicating whether the action was executed without errors.

INDEX.description: The unique identifier or index associated with a blockchain withdrawal transaction. It helps in keeping track of individual withdrawals and organizing them in a sequential or ordered manner.

VALIDATOR_INDEX.description: The identifier of the validator or node that approved or validated the withdrawal transaction. In proof-of-stake or similar consensus mechanisms, validators play a crucial role in ensuring the legitimacy of transactions, and this field ties a withdrawal to a specific validator.

ADDRESS.description: The destination address to which the withdrawn cryptocurrency is being sent. This address is usually a cryptographic public key or a combination of alphanumeric characters that uniquely identifies the recipient's wallet or account on the blockchain.

AMOUNT.description: The quantity of cryptocurrency being withdrawn in the transaction. It specifies the numerical value of the cryptocurrency units being transferred from the withdrawal source to the recipient's address.

UNIT.description: The type of cryptocurrency being withdrawn. It could be a symbol or code that represents the specific cryptocurrency asset being transferred, such as "BTC" for Bitcoin or "GWEI" for Ethereum.

ASSET_ID.description: The unique identifier for the asset the field is associated to.

SYMBOL.description: Internal mapped symbol for a specific asset

PROVIDER_KEY.description: Internal mapped Blockchain provider key for a specific asset

CHAIN_ID.description: This is the Id of the blockchain

IS_PART_OF_REORG.description: Is this block part of a reorg, this would happen when we get block reorgs due to a longer chain being published by some of the miners.

TIMESTAMP.description: The current block timestamp

RECEIVED_TIMESTAMP.description: The current block received timestamp

RECEIVED_TIMESTAMP_NS.description: The nanosecond part of the RECEIVED_TIMESTAMP field.

METADATA.description: The current block full metadata includes block data, transactions, logs.

PARENT_HASH.description: The hash of the previous block in the blockchain. It establishes the chronological link between blocks.

L1_BLOCK_NUMBER.description: The block number on Layer 1 where transactions are finalized.

CONFIRMATIONS.description: The number of blocks added to the blockchain after this block. More confirmations generally mean a higher degree of security and acceptance in the network.

VERSION.description: A version number indicating which set of block validation rules to follow. Miners can use this to signal readiness to enforce network upgrades.

ACTION_AUTHOR.description: This specifies the sender's address that initiated or triggered a specific action within a transaction. It identifies the entity or account responsible for the action, such as a user or a smart contract.

ACTION_REWARD_TYPE.description: The type of reward associated with the action, which might include mining rewards, staking rewards, or other types of incentives.

ACTION_ADDRESS.description: This is the contract whose code and storage are being removed from the blockchain.

ACTION_REFUND_ADDRESS.description: This is usually an external account or another contract that the remaining Ether is sent to.

ACTION_BALANCE.description: This amount will be transferred to the ACTION_REFUND_ADDRESS. Itâ€™s typically represented in wei (the smallest unit of Ether).

RESULT_ADDRESS.description: The address where the new contract is deployed.

RESULT_CODE.description: This is the actual code that will be stored and executed on the blockchain, distinct from the init code that was used to generate it.

RESULT_GAS_USED.description: The amount of gas actually consumed by the action during execution. This can be compared with the initial gas estimate to measure efficiency.

RESULT_OUTPUT.description: The output data produced by the action (encoded in hexadecimal), often used for reading the results of a contract call.

RESULT_ERROR.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the result, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *execution reverted*.

RESULT_STATUS.description: The status of the trace. Common values include "1" which means success and "0" which means failure, indicating whether the action was executed without errors.

RESULT_REVERT_REASON.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the result, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *fail*.

SUBTRACES.description: Indicates the number of subtraces created as a result of the action. Subtraces are typically generated when a complex transaction or contract call triggers multiple internal calls.

ERROR.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the action, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *Reverted* or *invalid opcode*.

STATUS.description: The overall status of the trace. Common values include "1" which means success and "0" which means failure, indicating whether the action was executed without errors.

LOGS.description: The chronological records of all activities such as transaction executions, contract interactions, errors, and changes that occur within a blockchain network.

ADDRESS.description: The address of the contract or account that generated the log entry. It serves as an identifier for the source of the event or action that triggered the log.

INDEX.description: The position of the log entry within the sequence of logs generated by a transaction. It's usually an incremental integer starting from 0 for the first log in a transaction. This field helps in distinguishing and organizing logs generated during a transaction.

DATA.description: This contains the arbitrary data associated with the log entry. This data can vary depending on the specific smart contract and event that generated the log. It might include relevant information about the state change or action represented by the log.

TOPICS.description: An array of one or more indexed event topics. These topics are hash values of event signatures or indexed arguments. They provide a way to filter and search for specific types of events within the logs efficiently.

REMOVED.description: A a boolean indicator that signals whether the log entry has been removed or undone due to a chain reorganization or a consensus rule change. It helps applications differentiate between active and reverted logs. It is "true" if log was removed, otherwise false.

BLOBS.description: The current transaction blobs, null when there are no blobs attached to the transaction.

HEX.description: The raw hexadecimal representation of the entire transaction data.

TRANSACTION_INPUTS.description: The source of funds for a Bitcoin transaction.

TX_ID.description: Transaction ID, a unique identifier for the transaction, calculated as the double SHA-256 hash of the transaction data.

INDEX_IN_TRANSACTION.description: The position of a specific input or output within a transaction.

SEQUENCE.description: A number used to specify the order of transaction.

COINBASE.description: A special type of transaction input that is used to reward miners with newly created bitcoins.

TRANSACTION_OUTPUTS.description: The destination of funds in a Bitcoin transaction.

REFUND_TO.description: The address to which any potential refunds from failed transactions or excess fees will be sent.

L1_BASE_FEE.description: The base fee required for transactions on Layer 1.

DEPOSIT_VALUE.description: The amount of cryptocurrency being deposited into the Layer 2 network.

RETRY_TO.description: The address to which a transaction should be retried or redirected.

RETRY_VALUE.description: The amount of value associated with a transaction retry.

RETRY_DATA.description: Additional data or parameters required for retrying a transaction.

BENEFICIARY.description: The recipient address designated to receive the cryptocurrency.

MAX_SUBMISSION_FEE.description: The maximum fee a user is willing to pay for submitting a transaction.

TICKET_ID.description: An identifier for a transaction ticket, used to track and manage queued or pending transactions.

MAX_REFUND.description: The maximum amount of funds that can be refunded in a transaction.

SUBMISSION_FEE_REFUND.description: The portion of the submission fee that is refunded if a transaction is not processed as expected.

ORPHAN_TRACES.description: Traces that were part of blocks that were not included in the main blockchain due to a fork or reorganization.

ID.description: This is a unique identifier generated by combining the root trace type + transaction hash + trace addresses if available

ACTION_GAS.description: The gas cost of executing the action. Gas is a measure of computational effort required for executing transactions and contract calls on the blockchain network.

RESULT_REVERT_REASON.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the result, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *fail*.

SUBTRACES.description: Indicates the number of subtraces created as a result of the action. Subtraces are typically generated when a complex transaction or contract call triggers multiple internal calls.

ERROR.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the action, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *Reverted* or *invalid opcode*.

STATUS.description: The overall status of the trace. Common values include "1" which means success and "0" which means failure, indicating whether the action was executed without errors.

INDEX.description: The unique identifier or index associated with a blockchain withdrawal transaction. It helps in keeping track of individual withdrawals and organizing them in a sequential or ordered manner.

VALIDATOR_INDEX.description: The identifier of the validator or node that approved or validated the withdrawal transaction. In proof-of-stake or similar consensus mechanisms, validators play a crucial role in ensuring the legitimacy of transactions, and this field ties a withdrawal to a specific validator.

ADDRESS.description: The destination address to which the withdrawn cryptocurrency is being sent. This address is usually a cryptographic public key or a combination of alphanumeric characters that uniquely identifies the recipient's wallet or account on the blockchain.

AMOUNT.description: The quantity of cryptocurrency being withdrawn in the transaction. It specifies the numerical value of the cryptocurrency units being transferred from the withdrawal source to the recipient's address.

UNIT.description: The type of cryptocurrency being withdrawn. It could be a symbol or code that represents the specific cryptocurrency asset being transferred, such as "BTC" for Bitcoin or "GWEI" for Ethereum.

ASSET_ID.description: The unique identifier for the asset the field is associated to.

SYMBOL.description: Internal mapped symbol for a specific asset

PROVIDER_KEY.description: Internal mapped Blockchain provider key for a specific asset

CHAIN_ID.description: This is the Id of the blockchain

IS_PART_OF_REORG.description: Is this block part of a reorg, this would happen when we get block reorgs due to a longer chain being published by some of the miners.

TIMESTAMP.description: The current block timestamp

RECEIVED_TIMESTAMP.description: The current block received timestamp

RECEIVED_TIMESTAMP_NS.description: The nanosecond part of the RECEIVED_TIMESTAMP field.

METADATA.description: The current block full metadata includes block data, transactions, logs.

ASSET_ID.description: The unique identifier for the asset the field is associated to.

SYMBOL.description: Internal mapped symbol for a specific asset

PROVIDER_KEY.description: Internal mapped Blockchain provider key for a specific asset

IS_PART_OF_REORG.description: Is this block part of a reorg? this would happen when we get block reorgs due to a longer chain being published by some of the miners.

TIMESTAMP.description: The current block timestamp

RECEIVED_TIMESTAMP.description: The current block received timestamp

NUMBER.description: The sequential order of the block within the blockchain. Each block's number is one greater than the number of the previous block.

TIMESTAMP.description: The exact time when the block was mined. It's a crucial piece of information for tracking the chronological order of blocks.

HASH.description: The unique identifier for the block, generated using cryptographic algorithms. It represents the content of the block and is used for verification and linking blocks together.

PARENT_HASH.description: The hash of the previous block in the blockchain. It establishes the chronological link between blocks.

L1_BLOCK_NUMBER.description: The block number on Layer 1 where transactions are finalized.

CONFIRMATIONS.description: The number of blocks added to the blockchain after this block. More confirmations generally mean a higher degree of security and acceptance in the network.

VERSION.description: A version number indicating which set of block validation rules to follow. Miners can use this to signal readiness to enforce network upgrades.

NONCE.description: This is a random number used in the process of mining. It's combined with other block data to create a hash that meets specific mining criteria.

BITS.description: The total amount of gas consumed by all transactions in the block. It helps in understanding the efficiency of transactions.

SHA3_UNCLES.description: This stores the hash of the block's uncles, which are valid blocks that were not included in the main blockchain but can provide additional rewards to miners.

LOGS_BLOOM.description: The bloom filter that allows for efficient querying of event logs.

TRANSACTIONS_ROOT.description: The hash of the root node of the Merkle tree that organizes the transactions in the block. It enables quick verification of included transactions.

STATE_ROOT.description: This hash represents the state of the blockchain after all transactions in the block have been executed. It's used to ensure the consistency of the blockchain's state.

MERKLE_ROOT.description: The Merkle root hash, which summarizes all the transactions included in the block. It ensures the integrity of the transactions.

RECEIPTS_ROOT.description: This is similar to the transactions root, the receipts root hash is the root of a Merkle tree, but it stores the receipts of transactions, including information about their success or failure.

SEND_COUNT.description: The total number of messages or transactions that have been sent from Layer 2 to Layer 1.

SEND_ROOT.description: Merkle root used to track messages sent from Layer 2 to Layer 1.

MINER.description: This specifies the address of the miner who successfully mined the block. This miner is rewarded with cryptocurrency for their effort.

MIX_HASH.description: This is a 256-bit hash value. It's essentially a part of the proof-of-work mechanism used in Ethereum to secure the blockchain. This hash is derived from the mixing of various components of the block, including the nonce, timestamp, previous block's hash, and more.

DIFFICULTY.description: This indicates how hard it was to mine the block. It's adjusted based on the overall network's hash rate to maintain a consistent block generation rate.

TOTAL_DIFFICULTY.description: This field accumulates the difficulty values of all previous blocks, providing a measure of the blockchain's security.

CHAIN_WORK.description: The total cumulative amount of work in the blockchain up to and including this block. It's a measure of the blockchain's security.

SIZE.description: The size of the block in bytes. It includes all the data and metadata within the block.

WEIGHT.description: A metric for the block's size that considers both the non-SegWit and SegWit data, used to ensure blocks remain within the maximum block weight.

BLOCK_TIME.description: The time taken in seconds between mining the previous and current block. It's an important metric for understanding the network's performance and stability.

MEDIAN_TIME.description: The median time of the last 11 blocks. It's used to ensure the network's time consistency.

EXTRA_DATA.description: This allows miners to include arbitrary information in the block. It's often used to add contextual information or messages.

GAS_LIMIT.description: The maximum amount of computational work a block can contain. Each transaction consumes a specific amount of gas, and this limit prevents abuse of the network's resources.

GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas consumed by all transactions in the block. It helps in understanding the efficiency of transactions.

TRANSACTION_COUNT.description: This indicates how many transactions are included in the block.

BASE_FEE_PER_GAS.description: The base fee for each unit of gas in transactions. It's part of Ethereum's fee market mechanism.

WITHDRAWALS_ROOT.description: The hash value that represents a data structure containing information about the withdrawals that occurred in the block.

BLOB_GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas used by blob transactions within the block.

EXCESS_BLOB_GAS.description: The amount of gas exceeding the standard limit for blob transactions.

HASH.description: Transaction internal mapped hash. (For BTC transactions without SegWit data, this is the same as the txid. For SegWit transactions, this represents the hash of the transaction including the witness data).

TX_ID.description: Transaction ID, a unique identifier for the transaction, calculated as the double SHA-256 hash of the transaction data.

TRANSACTION_TYPE.description: The EIP-2718 type of this transaction envelope

NONCE.description: The number of transactions made by the sender prior to this one encoded as hexadecimal. It prevents duplicate transactions and maintains order in the blockchain.

INDEX.description: The position of the transaction within the block. Helps in identifying the order of transactions in the block.

TO_ADDRESS.description: The address of the recipient. Null when its a contract creation transaction

VALUE.description: The amount of cryptocurrency being transferred from the sender to the recipient.

GAS.description: The amount of computational work a transaction requires to be executed. This is used to determine the fees paid by the sender to incentivize miners to include the transaction in a block.

LOGS_BLOOM.description: The bloom filter that allows for efficient querying of event logs.

L1_GAS_USED.description: The amount of gas used specifically by the current transaction.

L1_BLOCK_NUMBER.description: The block number on Layer 1 where the transaction was included.

L1_BASE_FEE_SCALAR.description: A scalar value used to adjust the base fee on Layer 1 for the transaction.

L1_BLOB_BASE_FEE.description: The base fee for processing blob transactions on Layer 1.

L1_BLOB_BASE_FEE_SCALAR.description: A scalar value used to adjust the blob base fee on Layer 1.

L1_FEE.description: The total fee paid for processing the transaction on Layer 1.

L1_GAS_PRICE.description: The price per unit of gas for executing the transaction on Layer 1.

DEPOSIT_NONCE.description: A unique number associated with the deposit transaction to ensure the uniquness and order of deposit transactions.

DEPOSIT_RECEIPT_VERSION.description: The version number of the deposit receipt, indicating the format version used.

GAS_PRICE.description: The price the sender is willing to pay for each unit of gas. Together with the gas limit, it determines the total fee for the transaction.

INPUT.description: The data associated with the transaction, often used in smart contract interactions. It can contain parameters and instructions for contract execution.

RECEIPT_BLOB_GAS_PRICE.description: The total gas price of the transaction blobs.

RECEIPT_BLOB_GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas used by the transaction blobs.

RECEIPT_CUMULATIVE_GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas used by the transaction and all preceding transactions within the same block.

RECEIPT_GAS_USED.description: The amount of gas used specifically by the current transaction.

RECEIPT_CONTRACT_ADDRESS.description: This is the address created when a contract is deployed. The *TO* field should be null in this case.

RECEIPT_ROOT.description: Only transactions included in blocks before the Byzantium Hard Fork have this field, as it was replaced by the *STATUS* field.

RECEIPT_STATUS.description: The status of a transaction is "1" if successful or "0" if it was a failure or reverted. Only transactions included in blocks post-Byzantium Hard Fork have this field.

MAX_FEE_PER_GAS.description: The maximum fee per gas unit that the sender is willing to pay for a transaction to be included promptly in a block.

MAX_PRIORITY_FEE_PER_GAS.description: The maximum fee per gas unit that the sender is willing to pay for higher priority processing of the transaction.

MAX_FEE_PER_BLOB_GAS.description: The maximum fee per gas unit that the sender is willing to pay for higher priority processing of the transaction.

RECEIPT_EFFECTIVE_GAS_PRICE.description: The total base charge plus tip paid for each unit of gas.

ACCESS_LIST.description: This causes a transaction to warm (i.e. pre-cache) another addresses state and the specified storage keys, Available on EIP-2930 transactions.

ADDRESS.description: Internal mapped Block Transaction Access address state

STORAGE_KEYS.description: An array of storage keys associated with the address mentioned above. Storage keys are unique identifiers used to access data within a smart contract's storage on the blockchain. Smart contracts often store data in a key-value format, where the storage keys are used to retrieve specific values.

ADDRESS.description: Internal mapped Block Transaction Access address state

STORAGE_KEYS.description: An array of storage keys associated with the address mentioned above. Storage keys are unique identifiers used to access data within a smart contract's storage on the blockchain. Smart contracts often store data in a key-value format, where the storage keys are used to retrieve specific values.

ECDSA_V.description: This is part of ECDSA (Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm) signature. This value helps to recover which public key was used to sign the transaction. Calculated as (CHAIN_ID * 2 + 35) or (CHAIN_ID * 2 + 36).

ECDSA_R.description: This is part of ECDSA (Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm) signature. It is derived from the private key and the data to be signed.

ECDSA_S.description: This is part of ECDSA (Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm) signature. It is derived from the private key and the data to be signed.

Y_PARITY.description: This is a recent addition from July 2023 and could be used instead of the ECDSA_V. ECDSA_V would be used for backward compatibility.

MEDIAN_TIME.description: The median time of the last 11 blocks. It's used to ensure the network's time consistency.

EXTRA_DATA.description: This allows miners to include arbitrary information in the block. It's often used to add contextual information or messages.

GAS_LIMIT.description: The maximum amount of computational work a block can contain. Each transaction consumes a specific amount of gas, and this limit prevents abuse of the network's resources.

GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas consumed by all transactions in the block. It helps in understanding the efficiency of transactions.

TRANSACTION_COUNT.description: This indicates how many transactions are included in the block.

BASE_FEE_PER_GAS.description: The base fee for each unit of gas in transactions. It's part of Ethereum's fee market mechanism.

WITHDRAWALS_ROOT.description: The hash value that represents a data structure containing information about the withdrawals that occurred in the block.

BLOB_GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas used by blob transactions within the block.

EXCESS_BLOB_GAS.description: The amount of gas exceeding the standard limit for blob transactions.

HASH.description: Transaction internal mapped hash. (For BTC transactions without SegWit data, this is the same as the txid. For SegWit transactions, this represents the hash of the transaction including the witness data).

TX_ID.description: Transaction ID, a unique identifier for the transaction, calculated as the double SHA-256 hash of the transaction data.

TRANSACTION_TYPE.description: The EIP-2718 type of this transaction envelope

NONCE.description: The number of transactions made by the sender prior to this one encoded as hexadecimal. It prevents duplicate transactions and maintains order in the blockchain.

INDEX.description: The position of the transaction within the block. Helps in identifying the order of transactions in the block.

TO_ADDRESS.description: The address of the recipient. Null when its a contract creation transaction

VALUE.description: The amount of cryptocurrency being transferred from the sender to the recipient.

GAS.description: The amount of computational work a transaction requires to be executed. This is used to determine the fees paid by the sender to incentivize miners to include the transaction in a block.

LOGS_BLOOM.description: The bloom filter that allows for efficient querying of event logs.

L1_GAS_USED.description: The amount of gas used specifically by the current transaction.

L1_BLOCK_NUMBER.description: The block number on Layer 1 where the transaction was included.

L1_BASE_FEE_SCALAR.description: A scalar value used to adjust the base fee on Layer 1 for the transaction.

L1_BLOB_BASE_FEE.description: The base fee for processing blob transactions on Layer 1.

L1_BLOB_BASE_FEE_SCALAR.description: A scalar value used to adjust the blob base fee on Layer 1.

L1_FEE.description: The total fee paid for processing the transaction on Layer 1.

L1_GAS_PRICE.description: The price per unit of gas for executing the transaction on Layer 1.

DEPOSIT_NONCE.description: A unique number associated with the deposit transaction to ensure the uniquness and order of deposit transactions.

DEPOSIT_RECEIPT_VERSION.description: The version number of the deposit receipt, indicating the format version used.

GAS_PRICE.description: The price the sender is willing to pay for each unit of gas. Together with the gas limit, it determines the total fee for the transaction.

INPUT.description: The data associated with the transaction, often used in smart contract interactions. It can contain parameters and instructions for contract execution.

RECEIPT_BLOB_GAS_PRICE.description: The total gas price of the transaction blobs.

RECEIPT_BLOB_GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas used by the transaction blobs.

RECEIPT_CUMULATIVE_GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas used by the transaction and all preceding transactions within the same block.

RECEIPT_GAS_USED.description: The amount of gas used specifically by the current transaction.

RECEIPT_CONTRACT_ADDRESS.description: This is the address created when a contract is deployed. The *TO* field should be null in this case.

RECEIPT_ROOT.description: Only transactions included in blocks before the Byzantium Hard Fork have this field, as it was replaced by the *STATUS* field.

RECEIPT_STATUS.description: The status of a transaction is "1" if successful or "0" if it was a failure or reverted. Only transactions included in blocks post-Byzantium Hard Fork have this field.

MAX_FEE_PER_GAS.description: The maximum fee per gas unit that the sender is willing to pay for a transaction to be included promptly in a block.

MAX_PRIORITY_FEE_PER_GAS.description: The maximum fee per gas unit that the sender is willing to pay for higher priority processing of the transaction.

MAX_FEE_PER_BLOB_GAS.description: The maximum fee per gas unit that the sender is willing to pay for higher priority processing of the transaction.

RECEIPT_EFFECTIVE_GAS_PRICE.description: The total base charge plus tip paid for each unit of gas.

ACCESS_LIST.description: This causes a transaction to warm (i.e. pre-cache) another addresses state and the specified storage keys, Available on EIP-2930 transactions.

ADDRESS.description: Internal mapped Block Transaction Access address state

STORAGE_KEYS.description: An array of storage keys associated with the address mentioned above. Storage keys are unique identifiers used to access data within a smart contract's storage on the blockchain. Smart contracts often store data in a key-value format, where the storage keys are used to retrieve specific values.

ADDRESS.description: Internal mapped Block Transaction Access address state

STORAGE_KEYS.description: An array of storage keys associated with the address mentioned above. Storage keys are unique identifiers used to access data within a smart contract's storage on the blockchain. Smart contracts often store data in a key-value format, where the storage keys are used to retrieve specific values.

ECDSA_V.description: This is part of ECDSA (Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm) signature. This value helps to recover which public key was used to sign the transaction. Calculated as (CHAIN_ID * 2 + 35) or (CHAIN_ID * 2 + 36).

ECDSA_R.description: This is part of ECDSA (Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm) signature. It is derived from the private key and the data to be signed.

ECDSA_S.description: This is part of ECDSA (Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm) signature. It is derived from the private key and the data to be signed.

Y_PARITY.description: This is a recent addition from July 2023 and could be used instead of the ECDSA_V. ECDSA_V would be used for backward compatibility.

TRACES.description: The detailed records of the steps and interactions that occured during the execution of this transaction.

ID.description: This is a unique identifier generated by combining the root trace type + transaction hash + trace addresses if available

TRACE_TYPE.description: The type of trace being recorded. It could be either "call", "reward", "suicide", "create", etc. depending on the type of action being traced

ADDRESS.description: This represents the address associated with the trace. This could refer to the contract address, external user address, or any other relevant address in the context of the blockchain transaction

ACTION_FROM.description: This specifies the sender's address initiating the action

ACTION_CALL_TYPE.description: The type of call made, such as "call", "delegate call", or "static call". This is relevant when one contract invokes another.

ACTION_GAS.description: The gas cost of executing the action. Gas is a measure of computational effort required for executing transactions and contract calls on the blockchain network.

ACTION_INIT.description: This is the bytecode that is executed to initialize the contract and determine its final code stored on the blockchain.

ACTION_INPUT.description: The input data for the action (encoded in hexadecimal). For contract calls, this data includes function signatures and parameters.

ACTION_TO.description: This specifies the recipient's address receiving the action, which could be a contract or an external address.

ACTION_VALUE.description: The value or amount of cryptocurrency involved in the action. This is particularly important for actions like transactions where cryptocurrency is transferred.

ACTION_AUTHOR.description: This specifies the sender's address that initiated or triggered a specific action within a transaction. It identifies the entity or account responsible for the action, such as a user or a smart contract.

ACTION_REWARD_TYPE.description: The type of reward associated with the action, which might include mining rewards, staking rewards, or other types of incentives.

ACTION_ADDRESS.description: This is the contract whose code and storage are being removed from the blockchain.

ACTION_REFUND_ADDRESS.description: This is usually an external account or another contract that the remaining Ether is sent to.

ACTION_BALANCE.description: This amount will be transferred to the ACTION_REFUND_ADDRESS. Itâ€™s typically represented in wei (the smallest unit of Ether).

RESULT_ADDRESS.description: The address where the new contract is deployed.

RESULT_CODE.description: This is the actual code that will be stored and executed on the blockchain, distinct from the init code that was used to generate it.

RESULT_GAS_USED.description: The amount of gas actually consumed by the action during execution. This can be compared with the initial gas estimate to measure efficiency.

RESULT_OUTPUT.description: The output data produced by the action (encoded in hexadecimal), often used for reading the results of a contract call.

RESULT_ERROR.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the result, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *execution reverted*.

RESULT_STATUS.description: The status of the trace. Common values include "1" which means success and "0" which means failure, indicating whether the action was executed without errors.

RESULT_REVERT_REASON.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the result, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *fail*.

SUBTRACES.description: Indicates the number of subtraces created as a result of the action. Subtraces are typically generated when a complex transaction or contract call triggers multiple internal calls.

ERROR.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the action, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *Reverted* or *invalid opcode*.

STATUS.description: The overall status of the trace. Common values include "1" which means success and "0" which means failure, indicating whether the action was executed without errors.

LOGS.description: The chronological records of all activities such as transaction executions, contract interactions, errors, and changes that occur within a blockchain network.

ADDRESS.description: The address of the contract or account that generated the log entry. It serves as an identifier for the source of the event or action that triggered the log.

INDEX.description: The position of the log entry within the sequence of logs generated by a transaction. It's usually an incremental integer starting from 0 for the first log in a transaction. This field helps in distinguishing and organizing logs generated during a transaction.

DATA.description: This contains the arbitrary data associated with the log entry. This data can vary depending on the specific smart contract and event that generated the log. It might include relevant information about the state change or action represented by the log.

TOPICS.description: An array of one or more indexed event topics. These topics are hash values of event signatures or indexed arguments. They provide a way to filter and search for specific types of events within the logs efficiently.

REMOVED.description: A a boolean indicator that signals whether the log entry has been removed or undone due to a chain reorganization or a consensus rule change. It helps applications differentiate between active and reverted logs. It is "true" if log was removed, otherwise false.

BLOBS.description: The current transaction blobs, null when there are no blobs attached to the transaction.

HEX.description: The raw hexadecimal representation of the entire transaction data.

TRANSACTION_INPUTS.description: The source of funds for a Bitcoin transaction.

TX_ID.description: Transaction ID, a unique identifier for the transaction, calculated as the double SHA-256 hash of the transaction data.

INDEX_IN_TRANSACTION.description: The position of a specific input or output within a transaction.

SEQUENCE.description: A number used to specify the order of transaction.

COINBASE.description: A special type of transaction input that is used to reward miners with newly created bitcoins.

TRANSACTION_OUTPUTS.description: The destination of funds in a Bitcoin transaction.

REFUND_TO.description: The address to which any potential refunds from failed transactions or excess fees will be sent.

L1_BASE_FEE.description: The base fee required for transactions on Layer 1.

DEPOSIT_VALUE.description: The amount of cryptocurrency being deposited into the Layer 2 network.

RETRY_TO.description: The address to which a transaction should be retried or redirected.

RETRY_VALUE.description: The amount of value associated with a transaction retry.

RETRY_DATA.description: Additional data or parameters required for retrying a transaction.

BENEFICIARY.description: The recipient address designated to receive the cryptocurrency.

MAX_SUBMISSION_FEE.description: The maximum fee a user is willing to pay for submitting a transaction.

TICKET_ID.description: An identifier for a transaction ticket, used to track and manage queued or pending transactions.

MAX_REFUND.description: The maximum amount of funds that can be refunded in a transaction.

SUBMISSION_FEE_REFUND.description: The portion of the submission fee that is refunded if a transaction is not processed as expected.

ORPHAN_TRACES.description: Traces that were part of blocks that were not included in the main blockchain due to a fork or reorganization.

SUBTRACES.description: Indicates the number of subtraces created as a result of the action. Subtraces are typically generated when a complex transaction or contract call triggers multiple internal calls.

ERROR.description: Records any errors encountered during the execution of the action, providing information about the nature of the error. Example: *Reverted* or *invalid opcode*.

STATUS.description: The overall status of the trace. Common values include "1" which means success and "0" which means failure, indicating whether the action was executed without errors.

INDEX.description: The unique identifier or index associated with a blockchain withdrawal transaction. It helps in keeping track of individual withdrawals and organizing them in a sequential or ordered manner.

VALIDATOR_INDEX.description: The identifier of the validator or node that approved or validated the withdrawal transaction. In proof-of-stake or similar consensus mechanisms, validators play a crucial role in ensuring the legitimacy of transactions, and this field ties a withdrawal to a specific validator.

ADDRESS.description: The destination address to which the withdrawn cryptocurrency is being sent. This address is usually a cryptographic public key or a combination of alphanumeric characters that uniquely identifies the recipient's wallet or account on the blockchain.

AMOUNT.description: The quantity of cryptocurrency being withdrawn in the transaction. It specifies the numerical value of the cryptocurrency units being transferred from the withdrawal source to the recipient's address.

UNIT.description: The type of cryptocurrency being withdrawn. It could be a symbol or code that represents the specific cryptocurrency asset being transferred, such as "BTC" for Bitcoin or "GWEI" for Ethereum.

ASSET_ID.description: The unique identifier for the asset the field is associated to.

SYMBOL.description: Internal mapped symbol for a specific asset

PROVIDER_KEY.description: Internal mapped Blockchain provider key for a specific asset

CHAIN_ID.description: This is the Id of the blockchain

IS_PART_OF_REORG.description: Is this block part of a reorg, this would happen when we get block reorgs due to a longer chain being published by some of the miners.

TIMESTAMP.description: The current block timestamp

RECEIVED_TIMESTAMP.description: The current block received timestamp

RECEIVED_TIMESTAMP_NS.description: The nanosecond part of the RECEIVED_TIMESTAMP field.

METADATA.description: The current block full metadata includes block data, transactions, logs.

ASSET_ID.description: The unique identifier for the asset the field is associated to.

SYMBOL.description: Internal mapped symbol for a specific asset

PROVIDER_KEY.description: Internal mapped Blockchain provider key for a specific asset

CHAIN_ID.description: This is the Id of the blockchain

IS_PART_OF_REORG.description: Is this block part of a reorg? this would happen when we get block reorgs due to a longer chain being published by some of the miners.

TIMESTAMP.description: The current block timestamp

RECEIVED_TIMESTAMP.description: The current block received timestamp

NUMBER.description: The sequential order of the block within the blockchain. Each block's number is one greater than the number of the previous block.

TIMESTAMP.description: The exact time when the block was mined. It's a crucial piece of information for tracking the chronological order of blocks.

HASH.description: The unique identifier for the block, generated using cryptographic algorithms. It represents the content of the block and is used for verification and linking blocks together.

PARENT_HASH.description: The hash of the previous block in the blockchain. It establishes the chronological link between blocks.

L1_BLOCK_NUMBER.description: The block number on Layer 1 where transactions are finalized.

CONFIRMATIONS.description: The number of blocks added to the blockchain after this block. More confirmations generally mean a higher degree of security and acceptance in the network.

VERSION.description: A version number indicating which set of block validation rules to follow. Miners can use this to signal readiness to enforce network upgrades.

NONCE.description: This is a random number used in the process of mining. It's combined with other block data to create a hash that meets specific mining criteria.

BITS.description: The total amount of gas consumed by all transactions in the block. It helps in understanding the efficiency of transactions.

SHA3_UNCLES.description: This stores the hash of the block's uncles, which are valid blocks that were not included in the main blockchain but can provide additional rewards to miners.

LOGS_BLOOM.description: The bloom filter that allows for efficient querying of event logs.

TRANSACTIONS_ROOT.description: The hash of the root node of the Merkle tree that organizes the transactions in the block. It enables quick verification of included transactions.

STATE_ROOT.description: This hash represents the state of the blockchain after all transactions in the block have been executed. It's used to ensure the consistency of the blockchain's state.

MERKLE_ROOT.description: The Merkle root hash, which summarizes all the transactions included in the block. It ensures the integrity of the transactions.

RECEIPTS_ROOT.description: This is similar to the transactions root, the receipts root hash is the root of a Merkle tree, but it stores the receipts of transactions, including information about their success or failure.

SEND_COUNT.description: The total number of messages or transactions that have been sent from Layer 2 to Layer 1.

SEND_ROOT.description: Merkle root used to track messages sent from Layer 2 to Layer 1.

MINER.description: This specifies the address of the miner who successfully mined the block. This miner is rewarded with cryptocurrency for their effort.

MIX_HASH.description: This is a 256-bit hash value. It's essentially a part of the proof-of-work mechanism used in Ethereum to secure the blockchain. This hash is derived from the mixing of various components of the block, including the nonce, timestamp, previous block's hash, and more.

DIFFICULTY.description: This indicates how hard it was to mine the block. It's adjusted based on the overall network's hash rate to maintain a consistent block generation rate.

TOTAL_DIFFICULTY.description: This field accumulates the difficulty values of all previous blocks, providing a measure of the blockchain's security.

CHAIN_WORK.description: The total cumulative amount of work in the blockchain up to and including this block. It's a measure of the blockchain's security.

SIZE.description: The size of the block in bytes. It includes all the data and metadata within the block.

WEIGHT.description: A metric for the block's size that considers both the non-SegWit and SegWit data, used to ensure blocks remain within the maximum block weight.

BLOCK_TIME.description: The time taken in seconds between mining the previous and current block. It's an important metric for understanding the network's performance and stability.

MEDIAN_TIME.description: The median time of the last 11 blocks. It's used to ensure the network's time consistency.

EXTRA_DATA.description: This allows miners to include arbitrary information in the block. It's often used to add contextual information or messages.

GAS_LIMIT.description: The maximum amount of computational work a block can contain. Each transaction consumes a specific amount of gas, and this limit prevents abuse of the network's resources.

GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas consumed by all transactions in the block. It helps in understanding the efficiency of transactions.

TRANSACTION_COUNT.description: This indicates how many transactions are included in the block.

BASE_FEE_PER_GAS.description: The base fee for each unit of gas in transactions. It's part of Ethereum's fee market mechanism.

WITHDRAWALS_ROOT.description: The hash value that represents a data structure containing information about the withdrawals that occurred in the block.

BLOB_GAS_USED.description: The total amount of gas used by blob transactions within the block.

EXCESS_BLOB_GAS.description: The amount of gas exceeding the standard limit for blob transactions.
